You will be playing 1 rounds of a game called deal-or-no-deal. 

Deal-or-no-deal is a two-player negotiation game. I, the user, will be the game coordinator, acting as a middleman between you and the other player. Your objective is to maximize your personal reward by proposing how to divide a set of items. All items must be distributed between you and the other player, and no items should be left over. The other player also aims to maximize their own reward, which may or may not align with your interests.

You are playing the vanilla variation of this game.
The reward you are trying to maximize is calculated as follow: your utility values multiplied by items you take.

Game Mechanics:
Turn-taking: You and the other player will take turns exchanging one message at a time. After enough exchanges, when you feel ready, you can finalize the negotiation by sending the division the game coordinator. Once a player decides to send a final division, the other player must also send a final division, ending the game.
Action: At the start of your turn, you will be asked to make an action (either messaging the other player or finalize the negotiation).
Final Division: The final division should specify how many of each item you want, leaving the remaining items for the other player. It should be JSON parsable. The final division is not visible to the other player, it should be made with caution and not for communication purposes.
Matching Divisions: If the combined division don't match the total number of items available, both players score 0.

Formatting:
Messages: <message> [Your message here.] </message>
Final division: <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items.

Only do one action per turn.

Exemples of how turns might proceed:
1. [Initial state is given]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

2. [The other player responds]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

3. [The other player agrees]
<finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>

The first round starts now.
Please decide how to divide {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10} between yourself and the other player.
To you, the items are worth: {'gold': 10, 'silver': 20}.

Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities.

Could you share your valuation of the items, even if it's just a relative value, so I can better understand your perspective and make an informed decision on adjusting our initial split. Considering this ratio, I would suggest starting with an initial allocation closer to 2:1, with the silver-to-gold ratio in mind. Considering this ratio, I would suggest starting with an initial allocation closer to 2:1, with the silver-to-gold ratio in mind. A possible alternative split could be 2 gold, 8 silver, allowing us to start negotiations from a clearer position regarding our valuations. What are your thoughts on this proposal? </message>

The other player said: 'I understand your valuation and appreciate your transparency. Based on your 2:1 ratio, an initial allocation of 2 gold, 8 silver seems more in line with your preferences, but still makes silver too valuable to me. Considering my own valuation doesn't see the silver as worth that much more than the gold, I could initially agree to offer starting with 3 gold and 7 silver, so we can still differentiate our valuations but move closer to my comfort level. This move may not be extreme, and we can likely adjust further from here.'

However, if we accept this split without a deeper understanding of the final outcome, we may end up leaving value on the table. I would like to propose a concession from your initial 7 silver to 6 silver, and in return, I am willing to consider giving up one of my gold, ending up with 2 gold and 6 silver. This adjustment allows us to balance the equation and move closer to a mutually beneficial agreement. </message>
